Type.Name: IAdvancedHoleElementData

Type.Remarks: Remarks IAdvancedHoleElementData is extended by the following: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICounterboreElementData">ICounterboreElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICountersinkElementData">ICountersinkElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IStraightElementData">IStraightElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IStraightTapElementData">IStraightTapElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITaperedTapElementData">ITaperedTapElementData</see> After accessing the IAdvancedHoleElementData object, cast it to a hole type-specific object using one of the interfaces above and set the hole type-specific properties. To create an Advanced Hole feature, see the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole">IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole</see> Remarks.

Type.Name: IAdvancedHoleFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to the Advanced Hole feature data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To create an Advanced Hole feature, see the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole">IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole</see> Remarks.

Type.Name: IAdvancedSaveAsOptions
Type.Description: Allows access to all File > Save As options when saving a SOLIDWORKS Part, Assembly, or Drawing.

Type.Name: IAdvancedSelectionCriteria
Type.Description: Allows access to advanced component selection criteria for an assembly.

Example.Name: Select Assembly Components Using Advanced Selection Criteria
Select Assembly Components Using Advanced Selection Criteria

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface represents functionality in the Advanced Component Selection dialog that appears when you click Standard toolbar > Advanced Select . As of SOLIDWORKS 2021, you can <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAdvancedSelectionCriteria.SaveCriteria">save</see> criteria only in XML format. You can now <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAdvancedSelectionCriteria.LoadCriteria">load</see> either *.xml queries or *.sqy legacy queries. For more information, see the Assemblies > Basic Component Operations > Selecting Components > Advanced Component Selection topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: IAngleMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to an angle mate or a limit angle mate feature.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Limit Angle Mate
Create and Edit Limit Angle Mate

Type.Remarks: Remarks An angle mate places selected items at a specified angle. A limit angle mate is an advanced mate that allows items to move within a range of angles. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate">IAngleMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate</see> to determine whether this is a limit angle mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create either an angle mate or a limit angle mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IAngleMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.ReferenceEntity">IAngleMateFeatureData.ReferenceEntity</see> or use IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2 to pre-select the reference entity using Mark = 67108864. Specify other properties of the AngleMateFeatureData object. To edit an angle mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to an AngleMateFeatureData object. Modify the AngleMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this angle mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IAnnotation
Type.Description: Allows access to notes, weld symbols, datum tags, display dimensions, blocks, cosmetic threads, center marks, centerlines, and other annotation types.

Example.Name: Get Whether Note Contains Rich-embedded Text
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks Because IAnnotation is a high-level representation of all annotation types, it provides functions that are generic to all types of annotations. For example, every annotation has a name and position, so IAnnotation provides functions that access this data. Although IAnnotation has specific lower-level objects (such as <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.INote">INote</see> ), it does not have any derived classes in the SOLIDWORKS API. This means that you cannot use an IAnnotation pointer to call functions in the lower-level objects. You also cannot use QueryInterface to obtain the underlying classes. Instead, SOLIDWORKS provides <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation.IGetSpecificAnnotation">IAnnotation.GetSpecificAnnotation</see> , which accesses underlying objects. Similarly if you are holding onto a lower-level class, then you can obtain the corresponding IAnnotation object using the GetAnnotation method of that class (see the

Type.Name: IAppearanceSetting
Type.Description: Allows access to visual property settings.

Example.Name: Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State

Type.Remarks: Remarks After implementing this interface: Set one or more properties in the IAppearanceSetting object. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetDisplayStateSetting">IModelDocExtension.GetDisplayStateSetting</see> to obtain an <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting">IDisplayStateSetting</see> object. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Names">IDisplayStateSetting.Names</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames">IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames</see> to specify the display states. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Entities">IDisplayStateSetting.Entities</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities">IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities</see> to specify the components. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Option">IDisplayStateSetting.Option</see> to specify the display state scope of the setting. Get or set the visual properties for the specified display states, components, and scope using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues">IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues</see> .

Type.Name: IAssemblyDoc
Type.Description: Allows access to functions that perform assembly operations; for example, adding new components, adding mate conditions, hiding, and exploding components.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The SOLIDWORKS API includes functions that are common to all document types; for example, determining the file name associated with a document is a common operation. To expose common document-level functions, the SOLIDWORKS API uses the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> object. Events are implemented with delegates in the Microsoft .NET Framework. See the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks_namespace">Overview</see> topic for a list of delegates for this interface.

Type.Name: IAttribute
Type.Description: Allows access to an attribute's values.

Example.Name: Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks An attribute is a piece of information that can be stored on a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IBody2">body</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2">component</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IEntity">entity</see> ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFace2">face</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IEdge">edge</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IVertex">vertex</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ILoop2">loop2</see> , or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature">feature</see> ), and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">model</see> if null. After you place an attribute on an object, you can get the IAttribute object and get or set its parameter values. For example, you can place an attribute containing NC machining information on a face. You can then use that attribute in automation on the shop floor to know what feed or speed to use during the machining process. You can also add attributes to a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">document object</see> . From the attribute instance you can get the: Attribute definition Associated entity Parameter values Instance name

Type.Name: IAttributeDef
Type.Description: Allows access to an attribute definition.

Example.Name: Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks An attribute definition is an application-specific data packet that is automatically saved with the SOLIDWORKS file and reloaded when the file is opened. An application can create <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttribute">attribute</see> data that is attached to an entity in a SOLIDWORKS document. The attribute definition describes a template for the data packet. The definition contains the names of the parameters in the attribute, their types and default values. It also allows you to create instances of the definition on entities in your model. The general sequence of steps in IAttribute creation is to: Create an attribute definition ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.DefineAttribute">ISldWorks.DefineAttribute</see> ) Add parameters to the attribute definition ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.AddParameter">IAttributeDef.AddParameter</see> ) Register the attribute definition ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.Register">IAttributeDef.Register</see> ) Create instances of the attribute definition on objects throughout the model ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.CreateInstance5">IAttributeDef.CreateInstance5</see> ) Perform Steps 1 through 3 only once for each working session. In other words, perform Steps 1 through 3 when your DLL or EXE is initially loaded or run. Until the DLL is unloaded or the EXE is closed, you can create an unlimited number of instances of the attribute definition.

Set the properties on IAutoBalloonOptions. Pass IAutoBalloonOptions in a call to <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc.AutoBalloon5">IDrawingDoc.AutoBalloon5</see> .

Type.Name: ICamFollowerMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a cam-follower mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A cam-follower mate: Allows you to mate a cylinder, plane, or point on a cam-follower part to the tangent faces of a cam part. Appears in the FeatureManager design tree as either CamMateCoincident or CamMateTangent. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a cam-follower mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICamFollowerMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ICamFollowerMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> for each EntityType or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1 for the cam face and Mark = 8 for the cam-follower face or vertex. Specify other properties of the CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. To edit a cam-follower mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. Modify the CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this cam-follower mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: ICenterMark
Type.Description: Allows access to a center mark or center mark set in a drawing view .

Example.Name: Get and Set Center Mark Set
Get and Set Center Mark Set
Get and Set Center Mark Set

Type.Remarks: Remarks Center marks are now annotations. Previously, center marks were features. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.GetAnnotation">ICenterMark.GetAnnotation</see> to access the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation">IAnnotation</see> APIs. If you use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObject6">ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObject6</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObjectType3">ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObjectType3</see> to retrieve center marks, then these values are returned: swSelCENTERMARKSSYMS = 100 for the center marks that are annotations swSelCENTERMARKS = 28 for the center marks that are features Both methods retrieve the ICenterMark object. To... Use... Traverse center marks that are annotations <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetFirstAnnotation3">IView.GetFirstAnnotation3</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation.GetNext3">IAnnotation.GetNext3</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetFirstCenterMark">IView.GetFirstCenterMark</see> , and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.GetNext">ICenterMark.GetNext</see> Retrieve center marks that are features <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetCenterMarkCount2">IView.GetCenterMarkCount2</see> and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetCenterMarks">IView.GetCenterMarks</see> Center marks are displayed using the document's default display attribute settings. If you want the setting to be local to this symbol, then set the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.UseDocDisplaySettings">ICenterMark.UseDocDisplaySettings</see> property to false and modify the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.ShowLines">ICenterMark.ShowLines</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.Size">ICenterMark.Size</see> , and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.CenterLineFont">ICenterMark.CenterLineFont</see> properties as needed. A center mark set is a linear or circular pattern.

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface supports the following chain component patterns: distance distance linkage connected linkage Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to populate the chain component pattern. Entity to select Corresponding Chain Pattern PropertyManager control Selection mark Number of selections 2D or 3D <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISketch">sketch</see> containing an open or closed loop, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISketchLine">Sketch line</see> , or Model <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IEdge">edge</see> Path 2 1 for all types of chain patterns Assembly <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2">component</see> Chain Group 1 Component to Pattern 1 1 for all types of chain patterns Cylindrical <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFace2">face</see> , Circular or linear edge, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISketchPoint">Sketch point</see> , <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IVertex">Vertex</see> , or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRefAxis">Reference axis</see> Chain Group 1 Path Link 1 256 1 for all types of chain patterns Cylindrical face, Circular or linear edge, Sketch point, Vertex, or Reference axis Chain Group 1 Path Link 2 512 1 for distance linkage or connected linkage None for distance Component <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRefPlane">plane</see> or planar face Chain Group 1 Path Alignment Plane 16384 1 for all types of chain patterns Assembly component Chain Group 2 Component to Pattern 2048 1 for connected linkage None for distance or linkage distance Cylindrical face, Circular or linear edge, Sketch point, Vertex, or Reference axis Chain Group 2 Path Link 1 4096 1 for connected linkage None for distance or linkage distance Cylindrical face, Circular or linear edge, Sketch point, Vertex, or Reference axis Chain Group 2 Path Link 2 8192 1 for connected linkage None for distance or linkage distance Component plane or planar face Group 2 Path Alignment Plane 32768 1 for connected linkage None for distance or linkage distance Assembly plane Face normal alignment 1024 1 if the chain path is a sketch line None for all other types of paths You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the chain component pattern feature.

Type.Name: ICoincidentMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a coincident mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A coincident mate: Positions the selected faces, edges, and planes so they share the same infinite plane. Positions two vertices so they touch. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a coincident mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICoincidentMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ICoincidentMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the CoincidentMateFeatureData object. To edit a coincident mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a CoincidentMateFeatureData object. You cannot change the entities to mate by pre-selection. You must use ICoincidentMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate to modify them. Modify other properties of the CoincidentMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this coincident mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: ICollision
Type.Description: Allows access to collision data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See the ICollisionDetectionManager remarks.

Type.Name: ICollisionDetectionGroup
Type.Description: Allows access to collision detection groups.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See the ICollisionDetectionManager remarks.

Type.Name: ICollisionDetectionManager
Type.Description: Allows access to the collision detection manager.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The purpose of this interface, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup">ICollisionDetectionGroup</see> , and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollision">ICollision</see> is to provide dynamic, high-efficiency collision detection among groups of components. Collision detection is performed exclusively between collision groups: neither within collision groups nor outside of them. Please use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IInterferenceDetectionMgr">IInterferenceDetectionMgr</see> if you need to perform static interference detection between components. Collision detection may be thought of as a series of collision detection frames. Each collision detection frame begins by setting a target assembly and two or more collision groups of components that are transformed to move to precise locations in model space. A collision detection frame may or may not end with a collision. NOTE : If a collision is detected, an ICollision object is created. Be aware that ICollision objects are volatile and should not be cached for later review. ICollision objects are invalidated when a new collision detection frame begins or whenever you: call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.IsCollisionPresent">ICollisionDetectionManager.IsCollisionPresent</see> . call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.GetCollisions">ICollisionDetectionManager.GetCollisions</see> . apply new transforms to collision group components. create new or modify existing collision groups. set a new target assembly. Because you cannot save ICollision objects for later review, you should record the collision detection frame setup and any resulting collision components and transforms before the next collision detection frame begins. The workflow to detect collisions: Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.SetAssembly">ICollisionDetectionManager.SetAssembly</see> to set the target assembly for collision detection. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.CreateGroup">ICollisionDetectionManager.CreateGroup</see> to create two collision groups. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup.SetComponents">ICollisionDetectionGroup.SetComponents</see> to populate each collision group. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup.ApplyTransforms">ICollisionDetectionGroup.ApplyTransforms</see> to transform components into working positions. Call ICollisionDetectionManager::IsCollisionPresent and/or ICollisionDetectionManager::GetCollisions to detect collisions. Inspect any resulting ICollision objects. (See the NOTE above.) Repeat steps 4-6 if you want to apply new transforms for the next collision detection frame. Repeat steps 2-6 if you want to change collision groups. Repeat steps 1-6 if you want to change the target assembly.

However, if your add-in removes the CommandManager tab upon exiting SOLIDWORKS, then any customizations made by users will be lost.

Type.Name: IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a complex corner treatment feature of a structure system.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface is: derived from <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData</see> . valid only if <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData.IgnoreCornerTreatment">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData.IgnoreCornerTreatment</see> is false. A complex corner is the position in a structure system where three or more members intersect. In the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface, the Complex Corner PropertyManager contains five lists that you can manage using the APIs in this interface and elsewhere: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentGroupFolder.GetCornerTreatments">Corner groups</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetTrimToolMember">Trim tool</see> member <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetBodyTrimMembers">Body trim</see> members <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetPlanarTrimMembers">Planar trim</see> members <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.UserDefinedTrimFaces">User defined trim</see> faces You can assign one member as a trim tool and use it to add or remove material from adjacent members. Other members are trimmed based on their designated trim orders and positions with respect to touching members. For more information, see: SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Corner Management > Trimming Complex Corners SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Corner Management > Examples of Complex Corner Management SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Complex Corner PropertyManager

Specify other properties of the ConcentricMateFeatureData object. To edit a concentric mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a ConcentricMateFeatureData object. Modify the ConcentricMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . Type.Name: IConvertSolidFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a convert solid feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To create a ConvertSolid feature: Ensure that the Sheet Metal tab is visible on the CommandManager toolbar. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select the fixed face (with Mark=0) and bend edges (with Mark=1). Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> (swFmSolidToSheetMetal) to create this feature data object. Instantiate and specify the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance">ICustomBendAllowance</see> object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.Initialize">IConvertSolidFeatureData.Initialize</see> . Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> to create the ConvertSolid feature. To modify a ConvertSolid feature: Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to obtain this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.AccessSelections">IConvertSolidFeatureData.AccessSelections</see> . Modify properties as needed. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> to finalize any changes or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IConvertSolidFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> if no changes were made. For more information about converting solids or surface bodies to sheet metal parts, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface online help > Sheet Metal > Comparing Sheet Metal Design Methods > Convert to Sheet Metal Tool topics.

Type.Name: ICoordinateSystemElement
Type.Description: Allows access to a coordinate system element.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The normal channel of feature editing (IFeature::CreateDefinition, IFeature::ModifyDefinition) will not work for features created with coordinate system elements. In order to edit a feature created with a coordinate system element, you must: Select the feature created with a coordinate system element. Call the IModelDocExtension::RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_EditFeature to open a PropertyManager dialog for the selected object. Call ISelectionMgr::GetSelectedObjectType3 to obtain the selection. Test whether the selection is a coordinate system element. If the selection is a coordinate system element, obtain the CoordinateSystemElement object. 'VBA '--------------------------------------------------------------------- ' Preconditions: ' 1. Open a part that contains an Axis1 created using a coordinate system element. ' 2. Open the Immediate window. ' ' Postconditions: ' 1. Examine the Immediate window to see the coordinate system element type as defined by swCoordSysElementType_e. ' 2. Examine the user interface. The specified coordinate system element should be selected. ' '--------------------------------------------------------------------- Option Explicit Dim swApp As SldWorks.SldWorks Dim swModel As SldWorks.ModelDoc2 Dim swSelMgr As SldWorks.SelectionMgr Dim iSelType As Long Dim isCoordSysElmSelected As Boolean Dim swCordSysElement As SldWorks.CoordinateSystemElement Dim boolstatus As Boolean Sub main() Set swApp = Application.SldWorks Set swModel = swApp.ActiveDoc boolstatus = swModel.Extension.SelectByID2("Axis1", "AXIS", 0, 0, 0, False, 0, Nothing, 0) swModel.Extension.RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_EditFeature, "" Set swSelMgr = swModel.SelectionManager iSelType = swSelMgr.GetSelectedObjectType3(1, -1) If iSelType = swSelCOORDSYS Then isCoordSysElmSelected = swSelMgr.IsCoordSysElementSelected(1, -1) If isCoordSysElmSelected Then Set swCordSysElement = swSelMgr.GetSelectedCoordSysElement(1, -1) Debug.Print "Element type: " & swCordSysElement.GetElementType End If End If swModel.Extension.RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_Dve_Rmb_Cancel, "" Set swCordSysElement = Nothing End Sub

Type.Name: ICustomBendAllowance
Type.Description: Allows access to the custom bend allowance of a feature.

Example.Name: Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data

Type.Remarks: Remarks In your application, the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance.Type">ICustomBendAllowance.Type</see> must always be set last, after the other properties of this interface have been set. The property last set automically overrides any previously set ICustomBendAllowance::Type. For example: cba. Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDeduction '***set first, so will not hold*** '***RESET THE VALUES*** cba. KFactor = 0.08 cba. BendDeduction = 0.1 cba. BendAllowance = 0.11 cba. BendTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba. BendCalculationTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba.Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect '***set last, so holds**** The above code sets the ICustomBendAllowance::Type as swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect. Another example: cba. Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDeduction '***set first, so will not hold*** '***RESET THE VALUES*** cba. KFactor = 0.08 cba. BendDeduction = 0.1 cba. BendAllowance = 0.11 cba. BendTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba. BendCalculationTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" ‘cba. Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect '***set last would hold**** BUT COMMENTED OUT The above code sets the ICustomBendAllowance::Type as swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceBendCalculationTable, because the last property set was BendCalculationTableFile. The last ICustomBendAllowance property that is set automatically re-sets the type of bend allowance. You can always explicitly specify the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance.Type">ICustomBendAllowance.Type</see> , but you must set it after all other properties of this interface have been set.

Type.Name: IDSPBRMaterial
Type.Description: Allows access to Dassault Systemes Physically Based Rendering (DSPBR) material object.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The Enterprise PBR Shading Model (DSPBR) is a high-quality, easy-to-use material optimized for performance in real-time and interactive scenarios, suitable for rasterization and ray tracing. Inspired by the Disney Principled BRDF and the Unreal Shading Model, it combines a metallic and a dielectric bidirectional scattering distribution function (BSDF), including transparency for thin-walled and volumetric objects. In addition, it provides effects like emission, clear coat, metallic flakes and sheen to cover a wide range of appearances. For the DSPBR design rationale and detailed mathematical description in terms of BSDF and related concepts, open https://dassaultsystemes-technology.github.io/EnterprisePBRShadingModel/spec-2025x.md.html in an internet browser. The properties in IDSPBRMaterial map to the appearance settings in the user interface, if the DSPBR appearance is activated in the user interface. To activate the DSPBR appearance in the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface: Select System Options > Display > Appearance Visual Style > DSPBR (Dassault Systemes Physically Based Rendering) . Open a model. Select MMGS in the unit system dropdown below the graphics area. Click Edit Appearance in the graphics toolbar. Click the DSPBR tab in the FeatureManager. Select Enerprise PBR Shading Model from the DSPBR Appearance Type dropdown.

Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the derived pattern feature. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select the seed components and pattern feature in any order using Marks: seed component = 1 pattern feature = 2 You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the derived pattern feature. N OTE : A derived pattern feature is also called a pattern driven pattern feature. For more information, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Assemblies > Basic Component Operations > Component Patterns > Pattern Driven Component Pattern PropertyManager topic.

Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . The variable pattern feature uses a table to store the dimensions and values of pattern instances. You can <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDimPatternFeatureData.ImportFromExcel">import tables</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDimPatternFeatureData.ExportToExcel">export tables</see> using this interface. Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the derived pattern feature. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select the reference geometry to drive the seed fature and the feature to pattern in any order using Marks: reference geometry to drive seed feature = 1048576 feature to pattern = 4 You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the derived pattern feature.

Type.Name: IDisplayDimension
Type.Description: Represents instances of dimensions displayed in parts , assemblies , drawings and sensors .

Example.Name: Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension

Type.Remarks: Remarks You can display a SOLIDWORKS dimension more than once. For example, you can bring the base-extrude dimension into three different views on a drawing. These three dimensions are referred to as display dimensions and are represented by the DisplayDimension object in the SOLIDWORKS API. The original base-extrude dimension is represented by the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDimension">Dimension</see> object in the SOLIDWORKS API. SOLIDWORKS stores many of the properties associated with a dimension with the underlying Dimension object. For example, you must get the Dimension object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayDimension.GetDimension">IDisplayDimension.GetDimension</see> to access or modify the underlying dimension value.

Type.Name: IDisplayStateSetting
Type.Description: Allows access to display state settings.

Example.Name: Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State

Type.Remarks: Remarks After accessing this interface: Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Names">IDisplayStateSetting.Names</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames">IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames</see> to specify the display states. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Entities">IDisplayStateSetting.Entities</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities">IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities</see> to specify the entities. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Option">IDisplayStateSetting.Option</see> to specify the display state scope of the setting. Get or set one or more of the following properties for the specified display states, entities, and scope: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayMode">IModelDocExtension.DisplayMode</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.Transparency">IModelDocExtension.Transparency</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.Visibility">IModelDocExtension.Visibility</see> Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetAppearanceSetting">IModelDocExtension.GetAppearanceSetting</see> to obtain an <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAppearanceSetting">IAppearanceSetting</see> object. Set the properties in the IAppearanceSetting object. Get or set the material properties for the specified display states, entities, and scope using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues">IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues</see> .

Type.Name: IDistanceMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a distance mate or a limit distance mate feature.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Limit Distance Mate
Create and Edit Limit Distance Mate

Type.Remarks: Remarks A distance mate places selected items at a specified distance. A limit distance mate is an advanced mate that allows components to move within a range of distances. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDistanceMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate">IDistanceMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate</see> to determine whether this is a limit distance mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create either a distance mate or a limit distance mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDistanceMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IDistanceMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the DistanceMateFeatureData object. To edit a distance mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a DistanceMateFeatureData object. Modify the DistanceMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a distance mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IDrawingComponent
Type.Description: Represents the referenced component in a drawing view.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This object ties the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2">IComponent2</see> object of the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc">IAssemblyDoc</see> object with the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView">IView</see> object of the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc">IDrawingDoc</see> object. This functionality allows an application to manipulate the drawing-related settings of a referenced component without having to preselect that component.

Type.Name: IDrawingDoc
Type.Description: Allows access to functions that perform drawing operations.

Example.Name: Activate Each View on Current Sheet
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block
Insert Revision Cloud into a Drawing

Type.Remarks: Remarks Creating, aligning, and accessing drawing views are a few of the functions you find on the IDrawingDoc object. The SOLIDWORKS API also includes functions that are common to all document types. For example, determining the file name associated with a document is a common operation. The SOLIDWORKS API uses the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> object to expose common document-level functions. Events are implemented with delegates in the Microsoft .NET Framework. See the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks_namespace">Overview</see> topic for a list of delegates for this interface.

Example.Name: Select Edges of All Holes on Face
Select Edges of All Holes on Face
Select Edges of All Holes on Face

Type.Remarks: Remarks In Microsoft Visual Studio 2008/MFC 9.0 or later, Microsoft added a new interface called IEntity. Your add-in might not compile if it uses both this interface and the SOLIDWORKS IEntity interface. Possible errors are: error C3121: cannot change GUID for class 'IEntity' error C2011: 'IEntity' : 'struct' type redefinition undefined symbol errors when linking add-ins that do a QueryInterface on IEntity To avoid errors, you can: Include the namespace when declaring an IEntity variable: SldWorks::IEntity ent Rename IEntity by adding the rename function to the import of sldworks.tlb : #import "sldworks.tlb" rename("IEntity", "SWEntity") and do any of the following: use SWEntity instead of IEntity in your code do a QueryInterface using the GUID constant of the renamed interface: pFace->QueryInterface( IID_SWEntity , (LPVOID*)&entity); do a QueryInterface using a GUID lookup of the renamed interface: pFace->QueryInterface (__uuidof(SWEntity), (LPVOID*)&entity);

Type.Name: IEnvironment
Type.Description: Allows you to analyze the text and geometry used to create a geometric tolerance symbol.

Example.Name: Analyze Text and Geometry in GTol Symbol
Analyze Text and Geometry in GTol Symbol
Analyze Text and Geometry in GTol Symbol

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface can be useful if you have a note that contains a geometric tolerance symbol and you want to translate that note. You can find the file containing the list of supported geometric tolerance symbols and their abbreviations in C:\ProgramData\SolidWorks\SolidWorks 20 nn \ lang \ english\gtol.sym . NOTE: All numeric values returned from IEnvironment are relative to a unit text height of 1.0; i.e., if a geometric tolerance symbol has a text height of 0.15, then multiply the numeric values returned by 0.15.

Type.Name: IExplodeStep
Type.Description: Allows access to an explode step in the explode view of the active assembly configuration.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface is valid only for assemblies. To access the explode steps of an explode view of multibody parts, see <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartExplodeStep">IPartExplodeStep</see> . If this is a subassembly explode step, then you can call only one method on this interface, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IExplodeStep.GetSubAssemblyExplodeSteps">IExplodeStep.GetSubAssemblyExplodeSteps</see> , to retrieve the nested explode steps of this subassembly explode step. The setter properties and methods of this interface: Always clear selection lists. Do not work if the Explode PropertyManager is open. Do not work if any component is being edited in the context of the assembly. To edit an explode step that is not a subassembly explode step: Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConfigurationManager.ActiveConfiguration">IConfigurationManager.ActiveConfiguration</see> to get the active configuration of the assembly. Access the explode step. See the

Type.Name: IExportPdfData
Type.Description: Allows access to the PDF export data interface, which allows you to save: one or more drawing sheets to PDF. parts and assemblies to 3D PDF.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To export one or more drawing sheets to PDF: Get the IExportPdfData object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks.GetExportFileData</see> . Set the sheets to export to PDF using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.SetSheets">IExportPdfData.SetSheets</see> . Set whether to view the PDF after saving using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving">IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving</see> . Save the sheets using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SaveAs">IModelDocExtension.SaveAs</see> . To export a part or assembly to 3D PDF: Get the IExportPdfData object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks.GetExportFileData</see> . Set <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ExportAs3D">IExportPdfData.ExportAs3D</see> to true. Set whether to view the PDF after saving using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving">IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving</see> . Save the part or assembly using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SaveAs">IModelDocExtension.SaveAs</see> .

Type.Name: IFillPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a fill pattern feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the fill pattern feature. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select... For the Fill Pattern's... Using Mark... Sketch, face, planar curve on a face, or coplanar faces Fill boundary 16384 Direction reference (e.g., edge or axis) Pattern direction (if not selected, SOLIDWORKS chooses a direction reference appropriate for the specified layout) 1 Vertex or sketch point Location of the pattern seed instance (if a point is not selected, the pattern seed instance is placed at the center of the fill boundary region) 3 Features Pattern objects 4 Faces Pattern objects 5 Bodies Pattern objects 6 After calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you can explicitly set other properties on the feature data object. You can also initialize: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.PatternLayoutType">IFillPatternFeatureData.PatternLayoutType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.LayoutSpacingType">IFillPatternFeatureData.LayoutSpacingType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.FeaturesToPatternType">IFillPatternFeatureData.FeaturesToPatternType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.GeometryPattern">IFillPatternFeatureData.GeometryPattern</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.LoopSpacing">IFillPatternFeatureData.LoopSpacing</see> (for all PatternLayoutTypes except <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swPatternLayoutType_e">swPatternLayoutType_e</see> .swPatternLayoutPerforation) Depending on the settings above, other properties might need to be initialized. You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the fill pattern feature. For all pattern layouts except swPatternLayoutType_e.swPatternLayoutPerforation, the fill pattern is created by positioning a pattern seed instance within the fill boundary and copying the pattern in concentric loops about the seed instance. See the Fill Pattern PropertyManager topic in the SOLIDWORKS Help for more information about fill pattern features.

Type.Name: IGearMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to gear mate features.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A gear mate forces two components to rotate relative to one another about selected axes. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a gear mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IGearMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IGearMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the GearMateFeatureData object. To edit a gear mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a GearMateFeatureData object. Modify the GearMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a gear mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

The filename extension for a general table is . sldtbt . Table templates are not supplied for general tables. Remarks .

Type.Name: IGroundPlaneFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a ground plane feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Use this interface to insert a ground plane at each level of a plant assembly. Ground planes are used as reference geometry when inserting published assets at each level. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.ActivateGroundPlane">IAssemblyDoc.ActivateGroundPlane</see> to activate the ground plane on the level where you want to insert a published asset; the asset's ground face snaps to the assembly's activated ground plane. Components with magnetic mates snap only to components that are also on the active ground plane. Only one ground plane can be active at a given time in each assembly configuration. See Large Assemblies > Facility Layout in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Description: Allows you to get and set geometric tolerance (GTol) parameters.

Example.Name: Get Text Items in GTol Frame
Get Text Items in GTol Frame
Get Text Items in GTol Frame
Set Text in Datum Tags and GTols
Set Text in Datum Tags and GTols
Set Text in Datum Tags and GTols

Type.Name: IGtolFrame
Type.Description: Allows access to indicators and XML strings for symbols in a Gtol feature control frame.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A geometric tolerance symbol adds geometric tolerances to parts and drawings using feature control frames. This interface extends <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IGtol">IGtol</see> by supporting the new SOLIDWORKS 2022 Gtol architecture and providing the ability to specify Gtol frames using XML: Left of Gtol you can add a single line of text and symbol (first frame only). Above Gtol you can add multi-line text and symbol (top frame only). Right of Gtol there can be indicator, datum, or text box. Multiple indicators are supported, but any text box must be at the end of the list of indicators. Text box can have only one line and symbol. Below Gtol there can be additional frames, text, between instruction, from-to instruction, separate requirement label (bottom frame only). For more information, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Detailing and Drawings > Annotations > Symbols > Geometric Tolerance Symbols topic.

Type.Name: IHingeMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a hinge mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A hinge mate: Limits the movement between two components to one rotational degree of freedom. Can also limit the angular movement between two components. Acts like a concentric mate and a coincident mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a hinge mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IHingeMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IHingeMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> for each EntityType or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1 for the concentric entities, Mark = 32768 for the coincident entities, and Mark = 65536 for the angle entities. Specify other properties of the HingeMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a hinge mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a HingeMateFeatureData object. Modify the HingeMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a hinge mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .
