Type.Name: IImport3DInterconnectData
Type.Description: Allows access to 3D Interconnect feature data.

Example.Name: Use 3D Interconnect to Import Third-Party Native CAD Files

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface requires 3D Interconnect. Enable 3D Interconnect by: Setting Tools > Options > System Options > Import > Enable 3D Interconnect . - or - Calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.SetUserPreferenceToggle">ISldWorks.SetUserPreferenceToggle</see> ( <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swUserPreferenceToggle_e">swUserPreferenceToggle_e</see> .swMultiCAD_Enable3DInterconnect, True). Access this interface after importing a third-party native CAD file into: an existing SOLIDWORKS part using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc.InsertImportedFeature">IPartDoc.InsertImportedFeature</see> . an existing SOLIDWORKS assembly using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.InsertImportedComponent">IAssemblyDoc.InsertImportedComponent</see> . a new SOLIDWORKS part using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks.LoadFile4</see> . a new SOLIDWORKS assembly using ISldWorks::LoadFile4. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Is3DInterconnectFeature">IFeature.Is3DInterconnectFeature</see> to determine whether a feature is a 3D Interconnect feature and whether this interface applies. ISldWorks::LoadFile4 imports into the appropriate native SOLIDWORKS part or assembly as follows: For both imported parts and assemblies, you can: Determine whether an update is required ( <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Is3DInterconnectUpdateAvailable">IFeature.Is3DInterconnectUpdateAvailable</see> ) and update the model ( <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Update3DInterconnectModel">IFeature.Update3DInterconnectModel</see> ). Edit the imported data using this interface, its accessor (IFeature::GetImportedFeatureParameters), or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.SetImportedFeatureParameters">IFeature.SetImportedFeatureParameters</see> . Break the link to the original third-party native CAD file using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.BreakLink">IFeature.BreakLink</see> . After you break a link, all references to the original CAD file are lost, and you can no longer change the features to transfer from the original file. For imported parts only, the native SOLIDWORKS file created is a copy of the original non-native file. The copy retains an external reference to the original third-party native CAD file. If the original CAD file is modified in its orginal application, the SOLIDWORKS copy can be updated to import those changes. Changes to the SOLIDWORKS copy do not propagate back to the original CAD file. For imported assemblies only, after import you must save the new SOLIDWORKS assembly in order for SOLIDWORKS to import and create a copy to edit. Only after saving the new SOLIDWORKS assembly can you edit the imported top-level assembly or break its reference links. Editing lower-level imported components or individually breaking their reference links is not supported. 3D Interconnect supports the following third-party native CAD file formats and versions: ACIS: .sat, .sab, .asat, .asab for r1 - 2018 1.0 Autodesk® Inventor: .ipt for V6-V2018, .iam for V11 - V2018 CATIA® V5: .CATPart, .CATProduct for V5R8 - V5-6R2017 IGES: .igs, .iges for up to 5.3 JT: .jt for JT 8.x, 9.x, and 10.x PTC®: .prt, .prt.*, .asm.* for Pro/ENGINEER® 16 - Creo 4.0 Solid Edge®: .par, .asm, .psm for V18 - ST10 STEP: .stp, .step for AP203, AP214, AP242 NX™ software: .prt for UG 11 - NX 11

Type.Name: IImportDxfDwgData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify values when importing or inserting DXF/DWG data.

Example.Name: Import DXF File into Part Sketch
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions

Type.Remarks: Remarks When importing DXF/DWG data, you can: Let SOLIDWORKS determine the default values: Paper size and sheet scale are computed to fit the input data. Length unit is determined from the header of the input DXF/DWG file. Sheet name is the same as the layout name in the input DXF/DWG file. - or - Set your own values by using: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetImportFileData">ISldWorks.GetImportFileData</see> to obtain the IImportDxfDwgData interface. Use the following methods with a Sheet argument of "" (an empty string), to set up your defaults before importing or inserting the file: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetPaperSize">IImportDxfDwgData.GetPaperSize</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetPosition">IImportDxfDwgData.GetPosition</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetSheetScale">IImportDxfDwgData.GetSheetScale</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.ImportMethod">IImportDxfDwgData.ImportMethod</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.LengthUnit">IImportDxfDwgData.LengthUnit</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetPaperSize">IImportDxfDwgData.SetPaperSize</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetPosition">IImportDxfDwgData.SetPosition</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetSheetScale">IImportDxfDwgData.SetSheetScale</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SheetName">IImportDxfDwgData.SheetName</see> NOTES: Getting the IImportDxfDwgData interface does not get default values from the input file. Any values not set by you are set to the values computed by SOLIDWORKS. If the DWG/DXF file has multiple sheets, use these methods with a valid layout name in the Sheet argument to set up sheet specific settings, which override the default settings. If any of the individual items are not specified for a given layout name, the value used is from the defaults (layout name ""). If the default value is not specified, SOLIDWORKS computes and uses a meaningful value for that item. When inserting DXF/DWG data as a feature into the current model document, first select a plane or planar surface and then call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.InsertDwgOrDxfFile2">IFeatureManager.InsertDwgOrDxfFile2</see> . Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks.LoadFile4</see> to import the DXF/DWG file as a new SOLIDWORKS model document.

Type.Name: IImportIgesData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify levels and values when importing IGES data.

Example.Name: Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File
Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File
Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File

Type.Remarks: Remarks If user preference <see cref="../swconst/FileOpenOptionsGeneral">swIGESImportShowLevel</see> is... Then the IGES translator... True Displays the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user where the user can specify levels and values. false and you retrieved IImportIgesData Does not display the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user and allows you to specify the levels and values. false and you did not retrieve IImportIgesData Does not display the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user and uses the default values. To specify levels and values when importing IGES data: 1. Set the user preference swIGESImportShowLevel to false. 2. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetImportFileData">ISldWorks.GetImportFileData</see> to get IImportIgesData. 3. Use the IImportIgesData functions to specify the levels and values. 4. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldworks.LoadFile4</see> to load the file.

Type.Name: IImportStepData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify values when importing STEP data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks.GetImportFileData</see> to get an IImportStepData interface pointer. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportStepData.MapConfigurationData">IImportStepData.MapConfigurationData</see> to specify how to map configuration data. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks.LoadFile4</see> to load the file. When IImportStepData is initialized, the current default environment setting, <see cref="../swconst/FileOpenOptionsGeneral">swImportStepConfigData</see> , initializes IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData unless you explicitly set IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData. Then the IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData setting overrides swImportStepConfigData for this import only.

Type.Name: IImportedCurveFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to an imported curve feature.

Type.Name: IIndentFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to an indent feature.

Type.Name: IInstanceToVaryOptions
Type.Description: Allows access to options for varying the dimensions and locations of instances in patterns for parts.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface is valid only if <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.InstancesToVary">ILinearPatternFeatureData.InstancesToVary</see> or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICircularPatternFeatureData.InstancesToVary">ICircularPatternFeatureData.InstancesToVary</see> is true. For more information about the Instance to Vary option, see the SOLIDWORKS Help > Parts and Features > Features > Patterns and Mirroring > Control and Modify Patterns > Varying Dimension Patterns topic.

Type.Name: IInterference
Type.Description: Allows access to the components that interfere when interference detection is calculated.

Type.Name: IInterferenceDetectionMgr
Type.Description: Allows you to run interference detection on an assembly to determine whether components interfere with each other.

Example.Name: Set Components and Transforms for Interference Detection
Set Components and Transforms for Interference Detection
Set Components and Transforms for Interference Detection

Type.Remarks: Remarks See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about interference detection. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager">ICollisionDetectionManager</see> to perform high-efficiency collision detection among groups of components transformed to a variety of positions.

Type.Name: IIntersectFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to an intersect feature.

Type.Name: IJogFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a jog feature.

Example.Name: Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data

Type.Name: IJoinFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a join feature.

Type.Name: ILayer
Type.Description: Allows access to the properties and items on a layer, including the color, width, name, etc., used to define the layer.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The ILayer interface is managed and accessible from the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ILayerMgr">ILayerMgr</see> interface. Layers are only supported in SOLIDWORKS drawing documents.

Type.Name: ILayerMgr
Type.Description: Allows you to manage a drawing document's layers.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Each drawing document has its own ILayerMgr object and its own <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ILayer">ILayer</see> objects. The ILayerMgr interface provides functions that allow you to manipulate and work with individual layers. This includes adding layers, setting the current layer, obtaining specific layers, etc. Layers are only supported in SOLIDWORKS drawing documents.

Type.Name: ILibraryFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to library feature data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Library_Features_and_LibraryFeatureData_Objects">Library Features and LibraryFeatureData Objects</see> .

Type.Name: ILibraryFormToolFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to library forming tool feature data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To create a library forming tool feature: Ensure that the Sheet Metal tab is visible on the CommandManager toolbar. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByRay">IModelDocExtension.SelectByRay</see> to select a flat face (with Mark = 0) on which to use a forming tool. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> (swFmFormToolInstance) to create this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.OverrideDocumentSettings">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.OverrideDocumentSettings</see> to specify flat pattern visibility options. Specify the forming tool and its rotation angle for placement using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.FormToolConfiguration">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.FormToolConfiguration</see> , <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.FormToolPath">FormToolPath</see> , <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.LinkToFormTool">LinkToFormTool</see> , and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.RotationAngle">RotationAngle</see> . Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> to create the feature. To modify a library form tool feature: Select a new location by clicking on a flat face in the graphics area where to re-position and/or replace the forming tool. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to obtain this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.AccessSelections">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.AccessSelections</see> . Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.SetPlacementFace">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.SetPlacementFace</see> to re-position the forming tool. Call ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::OverrideDocumentSettings to change the flat pattern visibility options. Modify ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::FormToolConfiguration, FormToolPath (a change to FormToolPath changes the feature name), LinkToFormTool, and RotationAngle. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> to finalize any changes or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> if no changes were made. Forming tools are dies that dent, bend, stretch, or otherwise form sheet metal. For more information about forming tools, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface online help > Sheet Metal > Using Forming Tools with Sheet Metal topics.

Type.Name: ILight
Type.Description: Allows access to the light feature.

Example.Name: Add Spotlight and Get Light Feature
Add Spotlight and Get Light Feature
Add Spotlight and Get Light Feature

Type.Name: ILightDialog
Type.Description: Obtained from a LightingDialogCreateNotify event.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Use this interface to add your own dialog information to the SOLIDWORKS lighting dialog.

Type.Name: ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to linear/linear coupler mate feature data.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Linear-Linear Coupler Mate
Create and Edit Linear-Linear Coupler Mate

Type.Remarks: Remarks A linear/linear coupler mate establishes a relationship between the translation of one component and the translation of another component. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this advanced mate interface. To create a linear/linear coupler mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity1">ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity1</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity2">ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity2</see> . Specify other properties of the LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a linear/linear coupler mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object. Modify the LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a linear/linear coupler mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: ILinearPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a linear pattern feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> , you must pre-select the entities needed to create the linear pattern feature. If... To select an entity, use... Using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select entities to pattern 1 to mark Direction 1 2 to mark Direction 2 4 to mark the faces or features to pattern 256 to mark the solid bodies to pattern 134217728 to mark the structure systems to pattern 2097152 to mark up-to references 8388608 to mark seed geometry references if not using centroids to measure offsets Directly selecting an entity <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IEntity.Select4">IEntity.Select4</see> with <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISelectData.Mark">ISelectData.Mark</see> = 1 to mark Direction 1 2 to mark Direction 2 <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Select2">IFeature.Select2</see> with Mark= 4 to mark the faces or features to pattern 256 to mark the bodies to pattern 134217728 to mark the structure systems to pattern 2097152 to mark up-to references 8388608 to mark seed geometry references if not using centroids to measure offsets After calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you can initialize the feature data object using: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1Axis">ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1Axis</see> to specify Direction 1. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.BodyPattern">ILinearPatternFeatureData.BodyPattern</see> to specify the type of seed entities to pattern: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternBodyArray">ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternBodyArray</see> , <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternFaceArray">PatternFaceArray</see> , or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternFeatureArray">PatternFeatureArray</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1EndCondition">ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1EndCondition</see> to specify either spacing and instances or offsetting from an up-to reference: If explicitly setting spacing and instances, use: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1Spacing">ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1Spacing</see> to specify spacing between pattern instances

Type.Name: ILocalCircularPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a circular component pattern feature in an assembly.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the local circular pattern feature. If... To select a component, use... Using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select components, ordered selection of the components is required 1 to mark the components to pattern 2 to mark the axis Directly selecting a component or axis <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISelectData.Mark">ISelectData.Mark</see> and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2.Select3">Component2.Select3</see> 1 to mark the components to pattern 2 to mark the axis You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the local circular pattern feature.

Type.Name: ILocalCurvePatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a curve-driven component pattern feature in an assembly.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> , you must pre-select the entities needed to create the curve-driven component pattern feature. To select ... Use Mark=... Components to pattern 1 Curve, edge, sketch, or sketch entity for Direction 1 2 Curve, edge, sketch, or sketch entity for Direction 2 4 Reference point (only needed if <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalCurvePatternFeatureData.D1ReferencePoint">ILocalCurvePatternFeatureData.D1ReferencePoint</see> is set to <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swLocalCurvePatternReferencePoint_e">swLocalCurvePatternReferencePoint_e</see> .swLocalCurvePatternSelectedPoint) 32 Face normal (face on which a 3D curve lies) 64 After calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you can explicitly set other properties on the feature data object. You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the curve-driven component pattern feature. For more information, see the Assemblies > Basic Component Operations > Component Patterns > Curve Driven Component Pattern topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a linear component pattern feature in an assembly.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> , you must pre-select the D1 and D2 end (and seed) reference entities to create the linear component pattern feature. If... To select an up-to entity (vertex, edge, face, or plane), use... To select a body, use... To select a component, use... Using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select entities, solid bodies, or components requires ordered selection Mark = 256 to select the Direction 1 end reference Mark = 512 to select the Direction 1 end seed reference Mark = 1024 to select the Direction 2 end reference Mark = 2048 to select the Direction 2 end seed reference Mark = 1 to mark Direction 1 Mark = 256 to mark the solid bodies to pattern Mark = 1 to mark the components to pattern Mark = 2 to mark Direction 1 and Mark = 4 to mark Direction 2 Directly selecting an entity, solid body, or component <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IEntity.Select4">IEntity.Select4</see> with: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISelectData.Mark">ISelectData.Mark</see> = 256 to select the Direction 1 end reference ISelectData::Mark = 512 to select the Direction 1 end seed reference ISelectData::Mark = 1024 to select the Direction 2 end reference ISelectData::Mark = 2048 to select the Direction 2 end seed reference IEntity::Select4 with ISelectData::Mark = 1 to mark Direction 1 <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IBody2.Select2">IBody2.Select2</see> with ISelectData::Mark = 256 to mark the bodies to pattern <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2.Select4">IComponent2.Select4</see> and ISelectData::Mark = 1 to mark the components to pattern IEntity::Select4 and ISelectData::Mark = 2 for Direction 1; Mark=4 for Direction 2 After calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you can further initialize the feature data object using: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1Axis">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1Axis</see> to specify Direction 1. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.SeedComponentArray">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.SeedComponentArray</see> to specify the pattern's seed components. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1EndCondition">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1EndCondition</see> to specify either spacing and instances or offsetting from an up-to reference: If explicitly setting pattern spacing and number of pattern instances, use: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1Spacing">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1Spacing</see> to specify spacing between pattern instances. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1TotalInstances">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1TotalInstances</see> to specify the number of pattern instances. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1ReverseDirection">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.D1ReverseDirection</see> to reverse Direction 1. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.RotateInstances">ILocalLinearPatternFeatureData.RotateInstances</see> to rotate pattern instances. If true:

Type.Name: ILocalSketchPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a sketch-driven component pattern feature in an assembly.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Read <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see> . Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the sketch-driven component pattern feature. To select ... Use a mark of... Components to pattern 1 Sketch to define the pattern 16 Reference point as defined in <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swLocalSketchPatternReferencePoint_e">swLocalSketchPatternReferencePoint_e</see> 32 You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the local sketch-driven pattern feature.

Type.Name: ILockMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to lock mate features.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A lock mate: Maintains the position and orientation between two components. Fully constrains the components. Is like a rigid subasssembly of components. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a lock mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILockMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ILockMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. To edit a lock mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a LockMateFeatureData object. Modify the LockMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this lock mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: ILoftFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a loft feature.

Example.Name: Get Guide Curves in Loft Feature
Get Guide Curves in Loft Feature
Get Guide Curves in Loft Feature

Type.Name: ILoftedBendsFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to display information for a lofted bends feature.

Type.Name: IMBD3DPdfData
Type.Description: Gains access to the details for publishing a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF.

Example.Name: Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF

Type.Remarks: Remarks SOLIDWORKS Model Based Definition (MBD) is an integrated drawingless manufacturing solution for SOLIDWORKS. This interface and its methods and properties require that the SOLDWORKS MBD add-in be loaded. ( <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadAddIn">ISldWorks.LoadAddIn</see> ) The MBD3DPdfData object corresponds to the SOLIDWORKS MBD Publish to 3D PDF PropertyManager page. Typical steps for generating a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using the SOLIDWORKS API are: Get the MBD3DPdfData object using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetMBD3DPdfData">IModelDocExtension.GetMBD3DPdfData</see> . Set the path and file name of the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF theme using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.ThemeName">IMBD3DPdfData.ThemeName</see> . Get standard and custom views using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetStandardViews">IMBD3DPdfData.GetStandardViews</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetMoreViews">IMBD3DPdfData.GetMoreViews</see> . Set standard and custom views using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.SetStandardViews">IMBD3DPdfData.SetStandardViews</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.SetMoreViews">IMBD3DPdfData.SetMoreViews</see> . Get and set text and custom properties in the theme using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetTextAndCustomProperties">IMBD3DPdfData.GetTextCustomProperties</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITextAndCustomProperty">ITextAndCustomProperty</see> . Set the path for the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.FilePath">IMBD3DPdfData.FilePath</see> . Generate the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.PublishTo3DPDF">IModelDocExtension.PublishTo3DPDF</see> . See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about MBD.

Type.Name: IMBDSTEP242Data
Type.Description: Allows access to the details for publishing a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D STEP242 file.
Type.Remarks: Remarks SOLIDWORKS Model Based Definition (MBD) is an integrated drawingless manufacturing solution for SOLIDWORKS. This interface and its methods and properties require that the SOLDWORKS MBD add-in be loaded. ( <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadAddIn">ISldWorks.LoadAddIn</see> ) The MBDSTEP242Data object corresponds to the SOLIDWORKS MBD Publish to STEP242 PropertyManager page. See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about MBD.

Type.Name: IMacroFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to the data that defines a macro feature.

Example.Name: Cut Body in Half Using Macro Feature
Assign Tracking ID Using Macro Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks Macro features can... For the rebuild function only, the macro associated with a macro feature cannot: be inserted into a part, assembly, or drawing document create multiple bodies edit multiple existing bodies insert a feature from a macro feature in the same model edit definitions of other features if these features are in the same model as the macro feature rebuild, roll back, or roll forward the FeatureManager design tree NOTE: These limitations are intended to prevent nested-feature regeneration in the model that contains the macro feature. When the feature is creating multiple bodies, then the return value from the rebuild function should contain the array of bodies that are the result of the operation. <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.EditBodies">IMacroFeatureData.EditBodies</see> is not expected to contain a body when the rebuild function returns to SOLIDWORKS. When the feature is modifying a body and the result is multiple bodies, then IMacroFeatureData::EditBodies should contain all of the resulting bodies. Whether creating multiple bodies or modifying a body that results in multiple bodies, call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.EnableMultiBodyConsume">IMacroFeatureData.EnableMultiBodyConsume</see> from the <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/Macro_Features/Rebuild_Function">rebuild</see> function to specify whether multiple bodies replace or append the original edit body in the FeatureManager design tree Solid Bodies folder. If your application allows the user to decide which bodies to keep, your application must determine what it means to select the bodies and subsequently store the selected bodies with the feature. To edit a macro feature in a drawing, do not use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.AccessSelections">IMacroFeatureData.AccessSelections</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.IAccessSelections">IMacroFeatureData.IAccessSelections</see> , or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IMacroFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> because the concept of a rollback bar does not exist. You can still use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IModifyDefinition2">IFeature.IModifyDefinition2</see> to update an IMacroFeatureData object. If the user decides to cancel the changes made to the IMacroFeatureData object, then discard the IMacroFeatureData object. This action is equivalent to using IMacroFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/Macro_Features/Overview_of_Macro_Features">Overview of Macro Features</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IMagneticLine
Type.Description: Allows access to a magnetic line.

Type.Name: IManipulator
Type.Description: Allows access to a manipulator, which is similar to the triad or the drag arrow (also called a handle), in a SOLIDWORKS part or assembly document.

Example.Name: Insert and Use Plane with Manipulator
Insert and Use Plane with Manipulator
Insert and Use Plane with Manipulator

Type.Remarks: Remarks An add-in application must create the handler for the manipulator. See <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swpublished.ISwManipulatorHandler2">ISwManipulatorHandler2</see> and <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Manipulators">Manipulators</see> for details.

Type.Name: IMassProperty2
Type.Description: Allows access to individual mass properties as found in the Mass Properties dialog box.
Type.Remarks: Remarks For more information, see the Mass Properties Dialog Box topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: IMassPropertyOverrideOptions
Type.Description: Allows access to mass property override options.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Mass property override options are available for only one selected body/component at a time. For more information, see the Mass Properties Dialog Box topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: IMate2
Type.Description: Allows access to various assembly mate parameters.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To get the IMate2 object, you must first get it as a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature">IFeature</see> object and then use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetSpecificFeature2">IFeature.GetSpecificFeature2</see> or QueryInterface to return the IMate2 interface. The IMate2 object is actually a subfeature beneath a MateGroup feature. To access the IMate2 subfeature by traversing the FeatureManager design tree, you can call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetFirstSubFeature">IFeature.GetFirstSubFeature</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IGetFirstSubFeature">IFeature.IGetFirstSubFeature</see> and then <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetNextSubFeature">IFeature.GetNextSubFeature</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IGetNextSubFeature">IFeature.IGetNextSubFeature</see> when the current feature type is MateGroup.

Type.Name: IMateControllerFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a mate controller feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To create a mate controller feature: Use IAssemblyDoc::IsSupportedMatesAvailable to determine whether supportive mates exist for the assembly. If true: Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CollectAllSupportiveMates">IAssemblyDoc.CollectAllSupportiveMates</see> . Pre-select the supportive mates to use to create the mate controller. Or call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.Initialize">IMateControllerFeatureData.Initialize</see> , passing in the supportive mates. Mates passed into the Initialize method are given precedence over pre-selected mates. The array passed in must contain IDispatch objects. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition</see> to create an IMateControllerFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.AddNewPosition">IMateControllerFeatureData.AddNewPosition</see> to add a new mate position to the mate controller. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.SetValues">IMateControllerFeatureData.SetValues</see> to set the values for all mates in a given mate position. If values are not specified or invalid values are specified, then the mate controller feature is created with default mate values (i.e., values used when the mate was created). Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> , passing in the IMateControllerFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.GetCreateFeatureErrors">IFeatureManager.GetCreateFeatureErrors</see> . To edit a mate controller feature, call: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.AccessSelections">IMateControllerFeatureData.AccessSelections</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IMateControllerFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> For more information about the Mate Controller feature, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Assemblies > Mates > Mate Controller topic.

Type.Name: IMathTransform
Type.Description: Provides a simplified interface for manipulating transformation matrix data.

Example.Name: Get Patterned Cosmetic Thread Annotations Data
Get Patterned Cosmetic Thread Annotations Data
Get Patterned Cosmetic Thread Annotations Data

Type.Remarks: Remarks Transformation matrix data: |a b c . n | |d e f . o | |g h i . p | |j k l . m | The SOLIDWORKS transformation matrix is stored as a homogeneous matrix of 16 elements, ordered as shown. The first 9 elements (a to i) are elements of a 3x3 rotational sub-matrix, the next 3 elements (j,k,l) define a translation vector, and the next 1 element (m) is a scaling factor. The last 3 elements (n,o,p) are unused in this context. The 3x3 rotational sub-matrix represents 3 axis sets: row 1 for x-axis components of rotation row 2 for y-axis components of rotation row 3 for z-axis components of rotation The 3 axes are constrained to be orthogonal and unified so that they produce a pure rotational transformation. Reflections can also be added to these axes by setting the components to negative. The rotation sub-matrix coupled with the lower-left translation vector and the lower-right corner scaling factor creates an affine transformation, which is a transformation that preserves lines and parallelism; i.e., maps parallel lines to parallel lines. If the 3 axis sets of the 3x3 rotational sub-matrix are not orthogonal or unified, then they are automatically corrected according to the following rules: If any axis is 0, or any two axes are parallel, or all axes are coplanar, then an identity matrix replaces the rotational sub-matrix. All axes are corrected to be of unit length. The axes are built to be orthogonal to each other in the prioritized order of Z, X, Y (X is orthogonal to Z, Y is orthogonal to Z and X).

Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> using selection Mark... Mirror plane 1 Components to mirror 2 Alignment references 4 To create a basic Mirror Component feature, use at a minimum: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorPlane">IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorPlane</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentsToInstanceAlignToComponentOrigin">IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentsToInstanceAlignToComponentOrigin</see> (Optional) <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorType">IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorType</see> (if not explicitly set, defaults to <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swMirrorComponentMirrorType_e">swMirrorComponentMirrorType_e</see> .swMirrorType_CenterOfBoundingBox) (Optional) <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentOrientationsAlignToComponentOrigin">IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentOrientationsAlignToComponentOrigin</see> (if not explicitly set, defaults to <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swMirrorComponentOrientation2_e">swMirrorComponentOrientation2_e</see> .swOrientation_MirroredX_MirroredY) To create a mirror instance as a copy of the component, positioned symmetrically about a plane in one of four orientations (for fully symmetric components, all four orientations are true mirrors), use: MirrorPlane MirrorType ComponentOrientationsAlignToComponentOrigin <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentOrientationsAlignToSelection">ComponentOrientationsAlignToSelection</see> ComponentsToInstanceAlignToComponentOrigin <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ComponentsToInstanceAlignToSelection">ComponentsToInstanceAlignToSelection</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.AlignmentReferences">AlignmentReferences</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.FlipDirections">FlipDirections</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.SyncFlexibleSubAssemblies">SyncFlexibleSubAssemblies</see> To create a new opposite-hand version of the component (a true mirror of a nonsymmetric component), positioned symmetrically about a plane, use: MirrorPlane MirrorType <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.CreateDerivedConfigurations">CreateDerivedConfigurations</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.OppositeHandComponents">OppositeHandComponents</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorComponentsFolderLocation">MirrorComponentsFolderLocation</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.PlaceFilesInOneFolder">PlaceFilesInOneFolder</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirroredComponentFilenames">MirroredComponentFilenames</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.NameModifier">NameModifier</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.NameModifierType">NameModifierType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.ReplaceFileLocations">ReplaceFileLocations</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.MirrorTransferOptions">MirrorTransferOptions</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.DimXpertScheme">DimXpertScheme</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.BreakLinksToOriginalPart">BreakLinksToOriginalPart</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMirrorComponentFeatureData.PropagateFromOriginalPart">PropagateFromOriginalPart</see> After specifying this interface as needed, call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> to create the feature. This interface is analogous in functionality to the Mirror Components PropertyManager. See the following topics in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help for more information: Comparing Types of Mirror Components Mirroring Components

Type.Name: IModelDoc2
Type.Description: Allows access to SOLIDWORKS documents: parts, assemblies, and drawings.

Example.Name: Get Names of Creators of Features

Type.Remarks: Remarks There are three main SOLIDWORKS document types: parts assemblies drawings Each document type has its own object ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc">IPartDoc</see> , <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc">IAssemblyDoc</see> , and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc">IDrawingDoc</see> ) with its own set of related functions. For example, the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.AddComponent4">IAssemblyDoc.AddComponent4</see> method exists on the IAssemblyDoc object because adding components is specific to assembly documents. The SOLIDWORKS API also has functions that are common to all document types. For example, printing, saving, or determining the file name associated with a document would be common operations. To expose common document-level functions, the SOLIDWORKS API uses the IModelDoc2 object.

Type.Remarks: Remarks Typical steps for creating a motion study's plot data and plot: Open an assembly model and create the motion study. Select the model's entities whose motion you want to measure. Perform the calculations and get the results. Create a plot feature data. Create the plot's x-axis and y-axis feature data objects. Set the type of plot. Select the result component. Set the entities for the x-axis and y-axis feature data objects. Get the plot's x-axis and y-axis values and insert and display the plot. Examine the examples to see the calls for these steps.

Type.Name: IParallelMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a parallel mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A parallel mate places selected items a constant distance apart. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a parallel mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IParallelMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IParallelMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the ParallelMateFeatureData object. To edit a parallel mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a ParallelMateFeatureData object. Modify the ParallelMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this parallel mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IParameter
Type.Description: Allows you to get and set values in an attribute.

Example.Name: Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature

Type.Name: IPartDoc
Type.Description: Provides access to functions that perform operations on parts in part documents.

Example.Name: Create Imported Surface Body From Sketch

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface provides functions that allow you to: create bodies and features. perform suppress operations. obtain part extents and tessellation. locate entities by name. The SOLIDWORKS API also has functions that are common to all document types. For example, determining the file name associated with a document would be a common operation. To expose common document-level functions, the SOLIDWORKS API uses the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> object. Events are implemented with delegates in the Microsoft .NET Framework. See the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks_namespace">Overview</see> topic for a list of delegates for this interface.

Type.Name: IPartExplodeStep
Type.Description: Allows access to the explode step of an explode view of a multibody part.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface is valid only for an active current explode view of a multibody part. To create an explode view of a multibody part, call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc.CreateExplodedView">IPartDoc.CreateExplodedView</see> . The setter properties and methods of this interface: Always clear selection lists. Do not work if the Explode PropertyManager is open. Do not work if any body is being edited in the context of the multibody part. To edit an explode step: Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc.ShowExploded">IPartDoc.ShowExploded</see> to activate the explode view of interest. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc.GetExplodedViewConfigurationName">IPartDoc.GetExplodedViewConfigurationName</see> to get the configuration for the explode view. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConfiguration.GetPartExplodeStep">IConfiguration.GetPartExplodeStep</see> to access the explode step of interest. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to select: Bodies to move with Mark = 1. An explode direction entity (cylindrical <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFace2">face</see> , conical face, linear <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IEdge">edge</see> , or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRefAxis">axis</see> ) with Mark = 2. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObject6">ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObject6</see> to get the bodies selected in step 4a. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartExplodeStep.SetBodies">IPartExplodeStep.SetBodies</see> , passing in the bodies gotten in step 4a. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartExplodeStep.SetExplodeDirection">IPartExplodeStep.SetExplodeDirection</see> , passing in the explode direction entity that was selected in step 4b. See Notes . Modify other explode step properties. Notes : When editing the object entity for the explode direction, please bear in mind: If... Then... Both object and manipulator index are valid Both object and manipulator index are set. Manipulator index is valid, but object is invalid Manipulator index is set, and object is unchanged. Object is valid, but manipulator index is invalid Object is set, and the manipulator index is reset to the Z direction index. Both object and manipulator index are invalid No values change. For more information, see Exploded Views in Multibody Parts topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help. To access explode steps of explode views of assemblies, see <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IExplodeStep">IExplodeStep</see> .

Type.Name: IPartialEdgeFilletData
Type.Description: Allows access to partial fillet/chamfer properties.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetErrorCode2">IFeature.GetErrorCode2</see> after creating the partial edge fillet feature to see if anything is wrong with the new feature. For more information, see the Partial Edge Parameters section of the Constant Size Fillets topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: IPerpendicularMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a perpendicular mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A perpendicular mate places selected items at a 90⁰ angle. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a perpendicular mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPerpendicularMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IPerpendicularMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the PerpendicularMateFeatureData object. To edit a perpendicular mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a PerpendicularMateFeatureData object. Modify the PerpendicularMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this perpendicular mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IPhysicalSimulationMotionStudyProperties
Type.Description: Allows access to a Physical Simulation motion study's properties.

Type.Name: IPhysicalSimulationMotionStudyProperties
Type.Description: Allows access to a Physical Simulation motion study's properties.

Type.Name: IProfileCenterMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to profile center mate feature data.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Profile Center Mate
Create and Edit Profile Center Mate

Type.Remarks: Remarks A profile center mate centrally aligns rectangular and circular profiles to each other and fully defines the components. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this advanced mate interface. To create a profile center mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IProfileCenterMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IProfileCenterMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the ProfileCenterMateFeatureData object. To edit a profile center mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a ProfileCenterMateFeatureData object. Modify the ProfileCenterMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a profile center mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IProfileGroupFolder
Type.Description: Allows access to a structure system profile group folder.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IStructureSystemFolder">IStructureSystemFolder</see> Remarks.

Type.Name: IProjectionArrow
Type.Description: Allows access to a projection arrow.

Type.Name: IProjectionCurveFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a projection curve feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To create a projection curve feature: Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the necessary entities using the following Marks: target faces on which to project a sketch = 1 sketch to project = 2 target sketch on which to project a sketch = 4 projection direction entity = 8 Call IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition(swFmRefCurve) to access this interface. Set non-entity properties on this interface. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager.CreateFeature</see> to create the projection curve feature. See the SOLIDWORKS Help for more information about projection curve features.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPage2
Type.Description: Provides add-in applications the ability to display and use views that have the look and feel of SOLIDWORKS PropertyManager pages.
Type.Remarks: Remarks OK and Cancel buttons are optional for IPropertyManagerPage2 objects, but a Help button is always displayed. If you do not want to implement help for your add-in, return false on help notification to display SOLIDWORKS Help. PropertyManager controls are displayed in a single, left-aligned column. Slight vertical spacing adjustment is available with the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageGroup.AddControl">IPropertyManagerPageGroup.AddControl</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageGroup.IAddControl">IPropertyManagerPageGroup.IAddControl</see> or the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPage2.AddControl">PropertyManagerPage2.AddControl</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPage2.IAddControl">IPropertyManagerPage2.IAddControl</see> Options argument. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetUserPreferenceInteger">IModelDocExtension.GetUserPreferenceInteger</see> (swPropertyManagerColorDivider,UserPrefOption) to get the color of the PropertyManager divider box backgrounds for custom bitmap color blending purposes. The returned integer value is the COLORREF value. The add-in application must implement the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swpublished.IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8">IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8</see> interface for data to be exchanged with the add-in application. The add-in application owns the IPropertyManagerPage2 object, which owns the IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8 for that page. The limits on the number of controls on a PropertyManager page are: Total number of controls = 300 (This number does not include group and selection boxes.) Total number of group boxes = 20 Total number of selection boxes = 15 NOTE : Number boxes count as 2 controls. All other controls count as 1 control. SOLIDWORKS does not allow suppressing components or features while a PropertyManager page is open. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPage2Handler9
Type.Description: Must be implemented by the add-in application to handle callbacks from IPropertyManagerPage2 .
Type.Remarks: Remarks To use this interface: In a SOLIDWORKS VBA macro, you must reference the SOLIDWORKS exposed type libraries for add-in use type library specific to the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.VersionHistory">version of SOLIDWORKS</see> that you are running. In a SOLIDWORKS VB.NET or C# add-in, you must reference the SOLIDWORKS.interop.swpublished assembly and set ComVisibleAttribute to true (see <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/ComVisibleAttribute_in_VSTA_macros">ComVisibleAttribute in VB.NET or C# Macros and Add-ins</see> ). For all unimplemented methods of this object, the add-in application can return E_NOTIMPL.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageActiveX
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page ActiveX control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information. See also <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Keystrokes_and_Accelerator_Keys_and_ActiveX_Modeless_Dialogs_and_PropertyManager_Pages">Keystrokes and Accelerator Keys to Handle ActiveX Modeless Dialogs and PropertyManager pages.</see>

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageBitmap
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page bitmap.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageBitmapButton
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page bitmap button control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Bitmaps are 256 colors. The standard bitmap buttons are 23 pixels wide x 23 pixels high; however, you can make them larger. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageButton
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page button control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Users can resize PropertyManager pages horizontally in SOLIDWORKS 2006 and later. This change in functionality affects the appearance of the buttons on PropertyManager pages created in SOLIDWORKS 2005 and earlier. In SOLIDWORKS 2005 and earlier, buttons remained aligned vertically at an indented position when a user resized a PropertyManager page. In most instances, these buttons are now centered when a user resizes a PropertyManager page. However, if a button on a PropertyManager page was aligned at the very left edge of the page and it was the only button on that line, then it is assumed that it was intentionally placed at that position and it will stay at that position if a user resizes the page. Any text on the button will also be left justified inside the button. If a button has a bitmap as its label, then the button remains next to the label instead of being centered. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageCheckbox
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page check box.

Example.Name: Set Focus on PropertyManager Page Control

Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page combo box control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageControl
Type.Description: Provides a set of methods and properties common to all PropertyManager page controls.

Example.Name: Show Bubble ToolTip for PropertyManager Page Control

Type.Remarks: Remarks These controls include: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageActiveX">IPropertyManagerPageActiveX</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageBitmap">IPropertyManagerPageBitmap</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageBitmapButton">IPropertyManagerPageBitmapButton</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageButton">IPropertyManagerPageButton</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageCheckbox">IPropertyManagerPageCheckbox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageCombobox">IPropertyManagerPageCombobox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageLabel">IPropertyManagerPageLabel</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox">IPropertyManagerPageListbox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageNumberbox">IPropertyManagerPageNumberbox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageOption">IPropertyManagerPageOption</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageSelectionbox">IPropertyManagerPageSelectionbox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageSlider">IPropertyManagerPageSlider</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageTab">IPropertyManagerPageTab</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageTextbox">IPropertyManagerPageTextbox</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageWindowFromHandle">IPropertyManagerPageWindowFromHandle</see> See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page group control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks You can have a maximum of 15 controls per PropertyManager page group. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageLabel
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page label control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageListbox
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page list box control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Implement the event handler <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swpublished.IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8.OnListboxRMBUp">IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8.OnListboxRMBUp</see> to position and display a menu when the right mouse button is released. By default, only one list item can be selected at a time. When another list item is selected, that item becomes the active item, and the previously selected item is cleared. To enable multi-selection, use swPropMgrPageListBoxStyle_MultipleItemSelect with <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox.Style">IProperytManagerPageListbox:Style</see> . These methods support multi-selection: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox.GetSelectedItems">IPropertyManagerPageListbox.GetSelectedItems</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox.IGetSelectedItems">IPropertyManagerPageListbox.IGetSelectedItems</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox.GetSelectedItemsCount">IPropertyManagerPageListbox.GetSelectedItemsCount</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageListbox.SetSelectedItem">IPropertyManagerPageListbox.SetSelectedItem</see> See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageNumberbox
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page number box control.

Example.Name: Cut Body in Half Using Macro Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks If you implement a... Then... Spin box an edit box with attached up and down arrow buttons for incrementing and decrementing the value is created. Combo box/spin box a text box with: a down-arrow button to display the attached drop-down list. You must set up and control the attached drop-down list up and down buttons for incrementing and decrementing the value is created. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPropertyManagerPageNumberbox.Style">IPropertyManagerPageNumberbox.Style</see> to select the type of combo-box/spin-box number box you want to implement. For both types of number boxes, SOLIDWORKS automatically validates the values and units. The up and down arrow buttons automatically increment and decrement the value. Both types of number boxes: Accept numerical expressions. Store all values as meters or radians and display them in the units specified in the current unit settings. NOTE: When a document's unit system is set to a non-metric setting, the dimension precision value (the number of digits displayed after a decimal point) is based on the number of digits specified. It is not based on the document's dimension precision settings. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageOption
Type.Description: Allows you to access to a PropertyManager page radio button control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageSelectionbox
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page selection box control.

Example.Name: Show Bubble ToolTip for PropertyManager Page Control

Type.Remarks: Remarks The behavior of your selection boxes imitates the behavior of SOLIDWORKS selection boxes, including: Filters that you can use to specify which types of objects can be selected for the selection box. Toggled object selection that selects objects on the first click, and clears them on the next click. Clear selections item on the shortcut menu in the model view. See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page slider control.

Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page tab control.
Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageTextbox
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page text box control.

Example.Name: Set Focus on PropertyManager Page Control

Type.Remarks: Remarks See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPropertyManagerPageWindowFromHandle
Type.Description: Allows you to access a PropertyManager page .NET control.

Example.Name: Add .NET Controls to SOLIDWORKS using an Add-in
Add .NET Controls to SOLIDWORKS using an Add-in

Type.Remarks: Remarks The add-in that deploys a .NET control in a PropertyManager page must implement the event handler <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swpublished.IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8.OnWindowFromHandleControlCreated">IPropertyManagerPage2Handler8.OnWindowFromHandleControlCreated</see> . SOLIDWORKS populates the arguments of this handler when it attempts to create a .NET control on the PropertyManager page. If SOLIDWORKS is unable to create a .NET control, it passes Status = false in the handler. When Status = false, the handler must return an action to take as defined in <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swHandleWindowFromHandleCreationFailure_e">swHandleWindowFromHandleCreationFailure_e</see> . See <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/Using_PropertyManagerPage2_and_the_Related_Objects">Using PropertyManagerPage2 and the Related Objects</see> for more information.

Type.Name: IPunchTable
Type.Description: Allows access to punch table information and values.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Punch tables contain information about the punches that are created by forming tools in sheet metal parts. A punch table contains the following information about pre-selected punches: Column Description TAG Datum tag added to each punch in the flat pattern view PUNCH ID Property of the forming tool or library feature X Location Distance from the x-axis to the point of insertion of the forming tool in the flat pattern view Y Location Distance from the y-axis to the point of insertion of the forming tool in the flat pattern view ANGLE Angle between the x-axis and the forming tool QUANTITY Number of times that the forming tool is used in the flat pattern view

Type.Name: IPunchTableAnnotation
Type.Description: Allows access to a punch table annotation.
Type.Remarks: Remarks The IPunchTableAnnotation object is derived from the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ITableAnnotation">ITableAnnotation</see> object.

Type.Name: IRackPinionMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a rack and pinion mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A rack and pinion mate consists of two components where: One component (the rack) causes circular rotation in another component (the pinion) and vice versa. Neither component is required to have gear teeth. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a rack and pinion mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 64 for the rack edge and Mark = 128 for the pinion face. Specify other properties of the RackPinionMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a rack and pinion mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a RackPinionMateFeatureData object. Modify the RackPinionMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this rack and pinion mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IRefPlaneFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to reference plane feature data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks Before calling any of the methods and properties on this interface, you should determine the reference plane's type because some IRefPlaneFeatureData methods and properties only work with constraint-based reference planes and some only work with non-constrained reference planes. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type2">IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type2</see> to determine the type of reference plane. If IRefPlaneFeatureData::Type2 returns swRefPlaneConstraintBase, then the reference plane is constraint based. To determine if a constraint-based reference plane has angle or offset distances references, call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type">IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type</see> : swRefPlaneAngle is returned for angle references. swRefPlaneDistance is returned for offset distance references. Otherwise, the reference plane is not constraint based. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type">IRefPlaneFeatureData.Type</see> to determine its type. NOTE: Reference planes created in SOLIDWORKS 2010 or later are constraint based; reference planes created in SOLIDWORKS 2009 or earlier are not. The following table shows which IRefPlaneFeatureData methods and properties to use with which types of reference planes. Method or property Constraint-based Constraint-based with angle or offset distance references Not constraint-based AccessSelections ? ? ? GetSelectionsCount ? ? ? IAccessSelections ? ? ? IGetSelections ? ? ? ISetSelections X ? ? ReleaseSelectionAccess ? ? ? Angle X ? ? AngleOrDistance ? ? X AutoSize X ? ? Constraint ? ? X Distance X ? ? OriginOnCurve X ? ? ProjectionType X ? ? Reference ? ? X ReverseDirection X ? ? Selections ? (get only) ? ? SolutionIndex X ? ? Type X ? ? Type2 ? ? X UseNormalPlane X ? ? ? = Yes X = No

Type.Name: IReferenceCurve

Type.Remarks: Remarks This includes the following types of curve features: 3D spline curves Curves from file Helix curves Imported curves IReferenceCurve does not expose reference curve features (for example, projected curves).

Type.Name: IRenamedDocumentReferences
Type.Description: Allows you to update references to a renamed file in unopened documents.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface corresponds to the Rename Documents dialog box in the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface. To update references to a renamed file in unopened documents: Set <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.UpdateWhereUsedReferences">IRenamedDocumentReferences.UpdateWhereUsedReferences</see> to true. Set <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.IncludeFileLocations">IRenamedDocumentReferences.IncludeFileLocations</see> to true to search the folders listed under Referenced Documents in Tools > Options > System Options > File Locations. Add or remove folders in which to search using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.AddSearchFolder">IRenamedDocumentReferences.AddSearchFolder</see> or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.RemoveSearchFolder">IRenamedDocumentReferences.RemoveSearchFolder</see> , respectively. Get the folders to search using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.GetSearchPath">IRenamedDocumentReferences.GetSearchPath</see> . Search for references using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.Search">IRenamedDocumentReferences.Search</see> . Get the references found in the previous step using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.ReferencesArray">IRenamedDocumentReferences.ReferenceArray</see> . Remove a reference from the update using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.RemoveReference">IRenamedDocumentReferences.RemoveReference</see> . Set <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IRenamedDocumentReferences.CompletionAction">IRenamedDocumentReferences.CompletionAction</see> to <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swRenamedDocumentFinalAction_e">swRenamedDocumentFinalAction_e</see> .swRenamedDocumentFinalAction_Ok.
