Expand or Collapse FeatureManager Design Tree Nodes
Expand or Collapse FeatureManager Design Tree Nodes

Type.Remarks: Remarks ITreeControlItem objects are released whenever the FeatureManager design tree is rebuilt (e.g., add or remove features, rebuild the model, etc.).

Type.Name: ITriadManipulator
Type.Description: Allows access to triad manipulators, which are: Similar to the SOLIDWORKS triad. Used to move and rotate assembly components, move/copy bodies, and so on.

Type.Name: ITwoMemberCornerTreatmentFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a two member corner treatment feature of a structure system.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface is: derived from <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData</see> . valid only if <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData.IgnoreCornerTreatment">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData.IgnoreCornerTreatment</see> is false. A two member corner is the position in a structure system where two members intersect. You can assign one member as a trim tool and use it to add or remove material from the other member. The trim tool member may be assigned to either member in a planar or body trim type. In the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface, the Two member Corner PropertyManager contains three lists that you can manage using the APIs in this interface and elsewhere: <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentGroupFolder.GetCornerTreatments">Corner groups</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITwoMemberCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetCornerGroupMembers">Corner group members</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITwoMemberCornerTreatmentFeatureData.MiterTrimPlanePoint">Miter trim plane point</see> For more information, see: SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Corner Management SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Two Member PropertyManager

Type.Name: IUniversalJointMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a universal joint mate feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A universal joint (U-joint) mate consists of two components where the rotation of one component (the output shaft) about its axis is driven by the rotation of another component (the input shaft) about its axis. An example would be the U-joint between the transmission and the rear drive axle of an automobile. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a universal joint mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Set <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.DefineJointPoint">IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.DefineJointPoint</see> to true and specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.JointPoint">IUniversalJointMateFeatureData.JointPoint</see> or use IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2 to pre-select the joint point using Mark = 16384. Specify other properties of the UniversalJointMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a universal joint mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a UniversalJointMateFeatureData object. Modify the UniversalJointMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete this universal joint mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: IUserNotificationDefinition
Type.Description: Allows access to a user notification of an add-in.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A user notification is an add-in dialog that: Allows an add-in to display a unique message to SOLIDWORKS Design users. Is modeless. May appear within the context of a document open in its own frame or within SOLIDWORKS itself. Replaces any previously displayed user notification. Requires an IUserNotificationHandler to handle user notification events.

Type.Name: IUserNotificationHandler
Type.Description: Must be implemented by the add-in application to handle callbacks from IUserNotificationDefinition .

Type.Name: IUserProgressBar
Type.Description: Allows access to a progress indicator that indicates how much longer a SOLIDWORKS operation will take.

Example.Name: Start, Update, and Stop Progress Indicator
Start, Update, and Stop Progress Indicator
Start, Update, and Stop Progress Indicator

Type.Remarks: Remarks The progress indicator appears on the SOLIDWORKS status bar.

Type.Name: IUserUnit
Type.Description: Allows you to manage units.
Type.Remarks: Remarks If you obtain IUserUnit using... Then IUserUnit's properties are... <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> Read only and persistent. Use IModelDocExtension::SetUserPreference* methods to set the units properties of a document. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks">ISldWorks</see> Read-write, but not persistent. The instance of IUserUnit returned by ISldWorks is empty and not tied to any document. Use this instance as a template to store units properties at runtime. NOTE : Use this interface instead of mo_UserUnits.h file in public_documents \appcomm of your SOLIDWORKS installation. If you previously used mo_UserUnits.h , you should change your applications to use this interface.

Create Variable Radius Asymmetric Elliptical Fillet
Create Curvature Continuous Variable Fillet Feature
Create Curvature Continuous Variable Fillet Feature
Create Curvature Continuous Variable Fillet Feature

Type.Remarks: Remarks To create a variable fillet feature, follow the instructions in the Remarks section of <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.FeatureFillet3">IFeatureManager.FeatureFillet3</see> . To edit a variable fillet feature: Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> . Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IVariableFilletFeatureData2.AccessSelections">IVariableFilletFeatureData2.AccessSelections</see> . Modify properties on this interface as needed and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . If nothing is modified, call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IVariableFilletFeatureData2.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IVariableFilletFeatureData2.ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> . For more information, read the Variable Size Fillets topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface allows you to get the associated edges in an enumerated list or the coordinates of the vertex.

Type.Name: IView
Type.Description: Represents drawing views found in a drawing document.

Example.Name: Get Drawing View Names and Types
Reposition Drawing Views to Avoid Overlap
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block
Get Notes from New or Existing Title Block

Type.Remarks: Remarks A drawing document can consist of one or more drawing sheets. Each drawing sheet typically contains one or more drawing views. Each drawing view is an oriented snapshot of a particular SOLIDWORKS model and a particular configuration of the model. The IView object lets you determine the particular model and configuration being viewed and to get information about all the objects in a drawing sheet or drawing view, as well as the drawing view bounds, and transforms.

Type.Name: IView3D
Type.Description: Allows access to a 3D View of a part or assembly.
Type.Remarks: Remarks This interface supports SOLIDWORKS Model Based Definition (MBD), which is an integrated drawingless manufacturing solution for SOLIDWORKS. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadAddIn">ISldWorks.LoadAddIn</see> to load the MBD add-in. See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about MBD.

Type.Description: Allows access to a weldment bead feature.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A bead can be applied to two sides: arrow or other. All of these methods and properties use one of these sides as input. A staggered type of weld bead requires applying the weld bead to both sides.

Type.Name: IWeldmentTrimExtendFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to the data that defines a weldment trim extend feature.

Example.Name: Get Weldment Trim Extend Corner Type
Get Weldment Trim Extend Corner Type
Get Weldment Trim Extend Corner Type

Type.Remarks: Remarks Only bodies created by weldment features can be trimmed and extended. Only End Trim corner types can have multiple target and boundary bodies to trim. All other corner types can have only one target and boundary body to trim. For all other corner types, first valid body specified is used if more than one body is specified.

Type.Name: IWidthMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to width mate feature data.
Type.Remarks: Remarks A width mate constrains a tab between two planar faces. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this advanced mate interface. To create a width mate: Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IWidthMateFeatureData.TabSelection">IWidthMateFeatureData.TabSelection</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the tab using Mark = 16. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IWidthMateFeatureData.WidthSelection">IWidthMateFeatureData.WidthSelection</see> or use IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2 to pre-select the width using Mark = 1. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IWidthMateFeatureData.ConstraintType">IWidthMateFeatureData.ConstraintType</see> . Specify other properties of the WidthMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a width mate: Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature.GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a WidthMateFeatureData object. Modify the WidthMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature.ModifyDefinition</see> . To delete a width mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2</see> .

Type.Name: swAppNotify_e Enumeration
Type.Description: Application notifications.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To receive notifications, a DLL application must register for the notifications by object type. This registration must be done for each instance of a particular object. For example, in the file in the Visual C++ 6.0 wizard-generated add-in that supports SOLIDWORKS events ( ATL_object_name >.h), include: BEGIN_SINK_MAP(C TL_object_name >) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_SLDWORKS_EVENTS, DIID_DSldWorksEvents, swAppDocumentLoadNotify, DocumentLoadNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_SLDWORKS_EVENTS, DIID_DSldWorksEvents, swAppFileNewNotify2, FileNewNotify2) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_SLDWORKS_EVENTS, DIID_DSldWorksEvents, swAppActiveDocChangeNotify, ActiveDocChangeNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_SLDWORKS_EVENTS, DIID_DSldWorksEvents, swAppActiveModelDocChangeNotify, ActiveModelDocChangeNotify) END_SINK_MAP() If developing a C++ application, use the enumerators to <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/events">register for notifications</see> for the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks">ISldWorks</see> events.

Type.Description: Categories for sorting bill of material table rows.
Type.Remarks: Remarks These enumerator options are used by <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IBomTableSortData.ItemGroups">IBomTableSortData.ItemGroups</see> to set the groupings for table sorting. For example, when you set IBomTableSortData::ItemGroups to the following array, assemblies are grouped first, parts are grouped second, and other categories are grouped last: <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swBomTableSortItemGroup_e">swBomTableSortItemGroup_e</see> .swBomTableSortItemGroup_Assemblies <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swBomTableSortItemGroup_e">swBomTableSortItemGroup_e</see> .swBomTableSortItemGroup_Parts <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swBomTableSortItemGroup_e">swBomTableSortItemGroup_e</see> .swBomTableSortItemGroup_Other

Type.Name: swBoundType_e Enumeration
Type.Description: Boundary behaviors at the start and end of UV parameter ranges.
Type.Remarks: Remarks If the behavior at the start of the U range is Degenerate', then the V parameter is degenerate when U = urange[0]'. The derivative of the parameterization function with respect to v is 0 whenever u = urange[0]', for all values of v, and the parameter curve corresponding to u = urange[0]' degenerates to a single point. A parameterization can only degenerate at the end of its range, unless the surface is a B-spline surface.

Type.Name: swDrawingNotify_e Enumeration
Type.Description: Drawing notifications.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To receive notifications, a DLL application must register for the notifications by object type. This registration must be done for each instance of a particular object. For example, in the file in the Visual C++ 6.0 wizard-generated add-in that supports drawing events (e.g., Drawing.h), include: BEGIN_SINK_MAP(CSwDrawing) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_DRAWINGDOC_EVENTS, DIID_DDrawingDocEvents, swDrawingDestroyNotify, DestroyNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_DRAWINGDOC_EVENTS, DIID_DDrawingDocEvents, swDrawingNewSelectionNotify, NewSelectionNotify) END_SINK_MAP() If developing a C++ application, use the enumerators to <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/events">register for notifications</see> for <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc">IDrawingDoc</see> events.

Type.Name: swFMViewNotify_e Enumeration
Type.Description: FeatureManager design tree notifications.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To receive notifications, a DLL application must register for the notifications by object type. This registration must be done for each instance of a particular object. For example, in the file in the Visual C++ 6.0 wizard-generated add-in that supports FeatureManager design tree events (e.g., FeatMgrView.h), include: DECLARE_REGISTRY_RESOURCEID(IDR_FeatMgrView) BEGIN_SINK_MAP(CFeatMgrView) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_FEATMGRVIEW_EVENTS, DIID_DFeatMgrViewEvents, swFMViewDestroyNotify , DestroyNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_FEATMGRVIEW_EVENTS, DIID_DFeatMgrViewEvents, swFMViewActivateNotify, ActivateNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_FEATMGRVIEW_EVENTS, DIID_DFeatMgrViewEvents, swFMViewDeactivateNotify , DeActivateNotify) END_SINK_MAP() If developing a C++ application, use these enumerators to <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/events">register for notifications</see> for <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeatMgrView">IFeatMgrView</see> events.

Type.Remarks: Remarks To receive notifications, a DLL application must register for the notifications by object type. This registration must be done for each instance of a particular object. For example, in the file in the Visual C++ 6.0 wizard-generated add-in that supports mouse events (e.g., Mouse.h), include: DECLARE_REGISTRY_RESOURCEID(IDR_MOUSE) BEGIN_SINK_MAP(CMouse) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_MOUSE_EVENTS, DIID_DMouseEvents, swMouseMoveNotify, MouseMoveNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_MOUSE_EVENTS, DIID_DMouseEvents, swMouseSelectNotify, MouseSelectNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_MOUSE_EVENTS, DIID_DMouseEvents, swMouseLBtnDownNotify, MouseLBtnDownNotify) END_SINK_MAP() If developing a C++ application, use these enumerators to <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/events">register for notifications</see> for the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMouse">IMouse</see> events.

Type.Name: swPropMgrPageNumberBoxStyle_e Enumeration
Type.Description: PropertyManager page number box styles. Bitmask .
Type.Remarks: Remarks When the user selects an item in the attached drop-down list, SOLIDWORKS attempts to use that item as a value in the number box. Thus, the items in the attached drop-down list should be numeric values and optionally include their units. The add-in then gets a callback via IPropertyManagerPage2Handler9::OnNumberboxChanged as if the user had typed a value in the number box or clicked the up-arrow or down-arrow buttons to increment or decrement the value. If you do not want your add-in to directly use items in the attached drop-down list in the number box, but instead want it to react to the user selecting a computed or linked value in the number box, then use swPropMgrPageNumberBoxStyle_AvoidSelectionText.

Type.Name: swPropSheetType_e Enumeration

Type.Remarks: Remarks This enumerator specifies possible values for the types of <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISWPropertySheet">ISWPropertySheet</see> s exported by SOLIDWORKS when a SldWorks notification of type <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swAppNotify_e">swAppPropertySheetCreateNotify</see> is sent. An example of a property sheet is the dialog that is displayed when you click Tools , Options . This dialog consists of a base property sheet and property pages stacked on top of it. To display a specific property page, click its tab.

Type.Name: swSmartDimensionDirection_e Enumeration
Type.Description: Smart dimension extension line directions or rapid dimensioning selector quadrants.
Type.Remarks: Remarks In parts, this enumerator is used to specify the extension line that is needed to unambiguously define the angle to dimension. In the user interface, a direction manipulator appears during dimensioning if selected entities do not fully specify the angle to dimension. This enumerator specifies the directions of that manipulator. In drawings that have Rapid dimensioning turned on, this enumerator may be used to specify the quadrant or side of the entities to which to add the display dimension. See <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.AddDimension">IModelDocExtension.AddDimension</see> .

Type.Name: swTaskPaneNotify_e Enumeration
Type.Description: Task Pane notifications.
Type.Remarks: Remarks To receive notifications, a DLL application must register for the notifications by object type. This registration must be done for each instance of a particular object. For example, in the file in the Visual C++ 6.0 wizard-generated add-in that supports Task Pane events (e.g., Taskpane.h, include: DECLARE_REGISTRY_RESOURCEID(IDR_TaskPane) BEGIN_SINK_MAP(CTaskPane) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_TASKPANE_EVENTS, DIID_DTaskpaneViewEvents, swAppTaskPaneDestroyNotify, DestroyNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_TASKPANE_EVENTS, DIID_DTaskpaneViewEvents, swAppTaskPaneActivateNotify, ActivateNotify) SINK_ENTRY_EX(ID_TASKPANE_EVENTS, DIID_DTaskpaneViewEvents, swAppTaskPaneDeactivateNotify, DeActivateNotify) END_SINK_MAP() If developing a C++ application, use these enumerators to <see cref="../sldworksapiprogguide/overview/events">register for notifications</see> for the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ITaskpaneView">ITaskpaneView</see> events.

Type.Remarks: Remarks swStandardSuperiorBottomingTappedHole2 249 = Superior - Tapped hole swStandardSuperiorEjectorPinClearances 239 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorEjectorPins 223 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorFlatHead100 229 = Superior - Countersink hole swStandardSuperiorFlatHead82 230 = Superior - Countersink hole swStandardSuperiorFlatSocket82 232 = Superior - Countersink hole swStandardSuperiorFractionalDrillSizes 234 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorHcoilTapDrills 233 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorLeaderPinClearances 242 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorLetterDrillSizes 240 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorNumberDrillSizes 235 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorOval 231 = Superior - Countersink hole swStandardSuperiorPipeTapDrills 236 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorReturnPinClearances 244 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorReturnPins 222 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorScrewClearances 237 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorSocketCapScrew 227 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorSpruePullerPinClearances 243 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorSpruePullerPins 224 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorStandardLeaderPins 228 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorStripperBolt 226 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorSupportPillarClearances 241 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorSupportPillarSHCS 225 = Superior - Counterbore hole swStandardSuperiorTapDrills 245 = Superior - Hole swStandardSuperiorTaperedPipeTap 248 = Superior - Piped tapped hole swStandardSuperiorTappedHole Obsolete ; see Remarks swStandardSuperiorTappedHole2 247 = Superior - Tapped hole Remarks If you used the now obsolete swStandardSuperiorTappedHole or swStandardSuperiorBottomingTappedHole enumerations with <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.HoleWizard2">IFeatureManager.HoleWizard2</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IWizardHoleFeatureData2.FastenerType2">IWizardHoleFeatureData2.FastenerType2</see> , then switch to using swStandardSuperiorTappedHole2 or swStandardSuperiorBottomingTappedHole2. If you recorded a macro, then the correct values may already be in use.
